ë¬¸ì œ

í•´ì„¤

292929 students and the teacher are going to buy the T-shirts, so the total number of people buying the T-shirts is 303030. Let a1a_{1}a1â€‹ as the quantity of small-sized T-shirts, a2a_{2}a2â€‹ as the quantity of medium-sized T-shirts, a3a_{3}a3â€‹ as the quantity of large-sized T-shirts, a4a_{4}a4â€‹ as the quantity of extra-large-sized T-shirts, and a5a_{5}a5â€‹ as the quantity of extra-extra-large-sized T-shirts. Since a1,â€…a2,â€…a3,â€…a4,â€…a5a_{1},\:a_{2},\:a_{3},\:a_{4},\:a_{5}a1â€‹,a2â€‹,a3â€‹,a4â€‹,a5â€‹ are in arithmetic progression and âˆ‘k=15ak=30\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{5}{a_k}=30k=1âˆ‘5â€‹akâ€‹=30, the arithmetic mean would be a3=305=6a_{3}=\displaystyle\frac{30}{5}=6a3â€‹=530â€‹=6. Since a4=4a_{4}=4a4â€‹=4, the common difference would be d=âˆ’2d=-2d=âˆ’2. Also, according to the passage, the small-sized T-shirt costs Â£10 and a bigger size means an additional Â£2. Based on this information, the following table can be made:

Size S M L XL 2XL Total
Quantity 10 8 6 4 2 30
Price per unit 10 12 14 16 18 -
Total Price(Â£) 100 96 84 64 26 380

The number of students buying the red cap is 272727 (of the 292929 students buying the T-shirts) +2 + 2+2 (of the 444 students not buying the T-shirts) =29=29=29. Since the woman says sheâ€™s buying the red caps for her students, it can be inferred that the woman is a teacher and she is not going to buy the red cap. Therefore, the total number of people buying the red cap is 292929. According to the question, the price of the red cap is set as aaa (an unknown value). Thus, the total price of the T-shirts and the red caps is Â£(380+29a)(380+29a)(380+29a).

Although applying the 10%-off coupon before the Â£20 discount coupon is cheaper, the question presumes that the man always applied the discounts in the wrong order. Thus, the Â£20 discount coupon was applied prior to the 10%-off coupon. The same mechanism applies to the Â£2 apology discountâ€”it was applied before the two coupons. Therefore, the price after applying the two coupons and an additional discount would be Â£{(380+29aâˆ’2âˆ’20)Ã—0.9}=\{(380+29a-2-20)\times 0.9\}={(380+29aâˆ’2âˆ’20)Ã—0.9}=Â£(26.1a+322.2)(26.1a+322.2)(26.1a+322.2).

The next step would be to apply the 10% VAT, which makes the total price Â£(28.71a+354.42)(28.71a+354.42)(28.71a+354.42). This is equivalent to $(28.71a+354.42)Ã—1.3=(37.323a+460.746)(28.71a+354.42)\times1.3=(37.323a+460.746)(28.71a+354.42)Ã—1.3=(37.323a+460.746). Only $600600600 can be paid with the corporate card, which is $(600Ã·0.95)=1200019(600 \div 0.95)=\dfrac{12000}{19}(600Ã·0.95)=1912000â€‹ before the 5%-off benefit of the corporate card. Therefore, the rest of the payment, which is $(37.323a+460.746âˆ’1200019)\left(37.323a+460.746-\dfrac{12000}{19}\right)(37.323a+460.746âˆ’1912000â€‹), was paid with US dollar cash.

The next step before deducting the quantity of each type of coin is to add the extra money the woman should pay. First of all, the $2 tip that the woman gave to the man should not be included in the coin quantity deduction process. This is because the man said the dimes, quarters, nickels, and the pennies are on the desk, while the $2 tip went to the manâ€™s pocket. Next, the woman paid an extra Â£5 for the shipping fee, which is equivalent to $5Ã—1.3=6.55\times1.3=6.55Ã—1.3=6.5. If we add this to the money that the woman paid in cash, the total would be $(37.323a+467.246âˆ’1200019)\left(37.323a+467.246-\dfrac{12000}{19} \right)(37.323a+467.246âˆ’1912000â€‹). The woman then paid a $50 bill and 333 dimes, which is a total of $50.3. Therefore, using 46âˆ’3=4346-3=4346âˆ’3=43 coins that include quarters, nickels, and pennies, the woman paid $(37.323a+416.946âˆ’1200019)\left(37.323a+416.946-\dfrac{12000}{19}\right)(37.323a+416.946âˆ’1912000â€‹). Let this value as nnn. We will now find the maximum and minimum values of nnn in order to specify aaa.

If the woman paid 414141 quarters, 111 nickle, and 111 penny, n=41Ã—0.25+1Ã—0.05+1Ã—0.01=10.31n=41\times0.25+1\times0.05+1\times0.01=10.31n=41Ã—0.25+1Ã—0.05+1Ã—0.01=10.31.

If the woman paid 111 quarter, 111 nickle, and 414141 pennies, n=1Ã—0.25+1Ã—0.05+41Ã—0.01=0.71n=1\times0.25+1\times0.05+41\times0.01=0.71n=1Ã—0.25+1Ã—0.05+41Ã—0.01=0.71.

0.71â‰¤37.323a+416.946âˆ’1200019â‰¤10.310.71 \leq 37.323a+416.946-\dfrac{12000}{19} \leq 10.310.71â‰¤37.323a+416.946âˆ’1912000â€‹â‰¤10.31
5.769âª…aâª…6.0265.769 \lessapprox a \lessapprox 6.0265.769âª…aâª…6.026

Since aaa is an integer, a=6a=6a=6. If we substitute a=6a=6a=6 in nnn,

n=37.323Ã—6+416.946âˆ’1200019â‰ˆ9.305n=37.323\times6+416.946-\dfrac{12000}{19}\approx9.305n=37.323Ã—6+416.946âˆ’1912000â€‹â‰ˆ9.305. Since the minimum payment is 111 cent, the woman has to pay $9.319.319.31 to pay the rounded price. Let x1=x_{1}=x1â€‹= the number of quarters the woman paid, x2=x_{2}=x2â€‹= the number of nickles the woman paid (excluding the nickles she paid as a tip), and x3=x_{3}=x3â€‹= the number of pennies the woman paid. We now have to solve the following indeterminate equation, given that x1,â€…x2,â€…x3âˆˆNx_{1},\: x_{2},\:x_{3} \in \mathbb{N}x1â€‹,x2â€‹,x3â€‹âˆˆN.

{x1+x2+x3=43â€‰â‹¯â€…(A)0.25x1+0.05x2+0.01x3=9.31â‹¯â€…(B)\begin{cases} x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=43 \qquad\qquad\qquad\quad\,\cdots\: \textrm{(A)} \\ 0.25x_{1}+0.05x_{2}+0.01x_{3}=9.31\quad \cdots\: \textrm{(B)} \end{cases}{x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹=43â‹¯(A)0.25x1â€‹+0.05x2â€‹+0.01x3â€‹=9.31â‹¯(B)â€‹

Multiplying 100100100 at (B) gives

{x1+x2+x3=43â‹¯â€…(A)25x1+5x2+x3=931â‹¯â€…(C)\begin{cases} x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=43\qquad\quad\cdots\:\textrm{(A)} \\ 25x_{1}+5x_{2}+x_{3}=931\quad\cdots\:\textrm{(C)} \end{cases}{x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹=43â‹¯(A)25x1â€‹+5x2â€‹+x3â€‹=931â‹¯(C)â€‹

Subtracting (A) and (C) leads to

24x1+4x2=88824x_{1}+4x_{2}=88824x1â€‹+4x2â€‹=888
6x1+x2=2226x_{1}+x_{2}=2226x1â€‹+x2â€‹=222

(â…°) If x1â‰¥37x_{1} \geq 37x1â€‹â‰¥37, then 6x1+x2â‰¥2226x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 2226x1â€‹+x2â€‹â‰¥222; This does not satisfy x2â‰¥1x_{2}\geq 1x2â€‹â‰¥1.

(â…±) If x1=36x_{1}=36x1â€‹=36, then x2=222âˆ’6Ã—36=6x_{2}=222-6\times36=6x2â€‹=222âˆ’6Ã—36=6, and x3=43âˆ’36âˆ’6=1x_{3}=43-36-6=1x3â€‹=43âˆ’36âˆ’6=1.

(â…²) If x1â‰¤35x_{1}\leq 35x1â€‹â‰¤35, then x2=222âˆ’6x1x_{2}=222-6x_{1}x2â€‹=222âˆ’6x1â€‹, which leads to x1+x2=222âˆ’5x1â‰¥47x_{1}+x_{2}=222-5x_{1}\geq 47x1â€‹+x2â€‹=222âˆ’5x1â€‹â‰¥47. However, since x3â‰¥1x_{3}\geq 1x3â€‹â‰¥1, this does not satisfy x1+x2+x3=43x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=43x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹=43.

Therefore, the woman paid 363636 quarters, 666 nickels, and 111 penny for the total price. Since she also tipped $2 with 2Ã·0.05=402\div 0.05=402Ã·0.05=40 nickels,

bbb (the total amount of nickels the woman paid) =6+40=46=6+40=46=6+40=46

âˆ´â€…a+b=6+46=52\therefore \: a+b=6+46=\boxed{\bm{52}}âˆ´a+b=6+46=52â€‹
